awd_titl_txt: Science in the Sierra Madre: developing infrastructure for multidisciplinary research at the CICHAZ field station
awd_abstract_narration:
This FSML improvement grant proposal addresses the infrastructure and shared instrumentation needs of the Centro de Investigaciones Cientificas de las Huastecas "Aguazarca" (CICHAZ) field station located in the Sierra Madre Oriental (http://www.cichaz.org/). CICHAZ is located in the unique Sierra y Huasteca region of central Mexico, an area high in biological and cultural diversity but devoid of academic and research institutions. This field station is associated with Texas A&M University and hosts an increasing number of scientists annually who need a broad array of scientific resources. Since its founding in 2005, CICHAZ has hosted over 150 researchers in the natural and social sciences from over 30 institutions internationally, fostered 9 Ph.D. and two Master's theses, and attracted 11 NSF-funded projects. CICHAZ has provided research and cultural experiences for undergraduates, local residents, and members of the U.S. public. In addition to long-term lodging for up to 11 researchers, the station has built up facilities including an indoor fishroom, an array of 24 aquatic mesocosms, and a small laboratory for molecular biology. This award will provide the infrastructure and equipment for collecting and analyzing genomic data; controlled husbandry of plants and animals; and ecological and evolutionary studies in the region. 

With this grant, an existing laboratory will be converted into a standard molecular wet lab, featuring a MinIon genome sequencer. This will enable researchers to collect and analyze nucleic acid data in situ within the course of a field stay. Two new greenhouse facilities will be erected to house animals and plants for controlled studies, as well as sustainable improvements to address the anticipated increase in energy needs. Finally, the station will acquire a mobile laboratory flexibly equipped with instruments for stream sampling, water quality analysis, and sedimentary core extraction. These proposed improvements have fundamental impacts on outreach efforts, and will ensure success of broader impacts initiatives including research experiences for US and Mexican undergraduates, and for local K-12 students, focused on integrating field and environmental approaches with state-of-the-art techniques for measurement and analysis. The mobile laboratory will revolutionize engagement with schools and with remote indigenous communities, by enabling visiting researchers to work with staff in designing outreach programs in local communities.

por.por_cntn:
This FSML improvement grant addressed the infrastructure and instrumentation needs of scientists working at the Centro de Investigaciones Científicas de las Huastecas “Aguazarca” (CICHAZ) field station located in the Sierra Madre Oriental of central Mexico.

The major goals of the grant were to:

1)    Build a state-of the-art molecular laboratory to serve as an invaluable tool for data collection, training, and outreach.

2)    Expand the vivarium facilities at CICHAZ, enabling researchers to complement field and mesocosm assays with finely controlled studies.

3)    Establish a mobile laboratory to transport key major equipment of broad use to field scientists, and to serve as a working learning laboratory to local populations throughout the region.

4)    Install sustainable energy at the CICHAZ field station to supply reliable power for the above initiatives.

Intellectual Merit: The construction of a state-of-the-art molecular laboratory for collecting and analyzing genomic data allowed us to convert our existing laboratory into a standard molecular wet lab so we can now perform basic fragment analysis and cDNA library preparation within the course of a field stay. The only such resource in the Sierra y Huasteca region of Mexico, the lab now supports the work of researchers from the U.S., Mexico, and other countries on-site whose studies include hybridization, soil quality, beetle diversity, sustainable and regenerative ranching, animal behavior, melanomagenesis, and riparian health. By bringing optimized vivarium facilities to CICHAZ, researchers complement their field and mesocosm assays with finely controlled studies. The purchase and refurbishing of a truck that is now a mobile laboratory is key for transporting major equipment of broad use to field scientists and is a valuable resource for ecological and evolutionary studies in the region, increasing the range of projects that can be conducted at CICHAZ. The mobile laboratory also serves as a working learning laboratory to Indigenous and mestizo populations throughout the region. In addition, the grant supported the installation of solar panels and a generator to promote using reliable, sustainable energy at the CICHAZ field station to supply power for the first two initiatives discussed above.

Broader Impacts: The expansion of CICHAZ’s resources has enabled us to provide more extensive research experiences for undergraduates and graduate students who are focused on integrating field and environmental approaches with state-of-the-art techniques for measurement and analysis. With the new facilities, CICHAZ has attracted a wide range of scientists and now collaborates with research teams from around the world studying topics such as soil macrofaunal, ranching practices, riparian habitat health, and regenerative ranching. The findings of these projects have been presented in over 25 presentations and conferences. By installing solar panels, a solar water heater, a recirculating filtration system for outdoor stock tanks, and other energy saving equipment, CICHAZ has also become a model for other field stations looking to improve their efficiencies when operating in similar settings. The mobile laboratory has revolutionized our engagement with schools and with remote Indigenous communities. The truck itself has become an educational tool as its surfaces now feature drawings depicting healthy and unhealthy flora and fauna throughout the local habitat. In collaboration with a Mexican graphic artist and a local non-profit, CICHAZ has been able to create a visual playground to teach about the local ecosystem and human impacts. In addition, these resources are making it possible to develop outreach programs that promote conservation across all age groups, as well as citizen science initiatives tailored to local educational needs and that will help CICHAZ scientists advance their investigations.
